bibl.title: Report: The Preferential and Compulsory Breeding Places of Some Disease Bearing Mosquitoes and the Limits Which Determine the Latter, by Henry Rose Carter, [19--]

div1.p: Carter reports on the breeding habits of the Anopheles mosquito.

div1.head: Report: The Preferential and Compulsory Breeding Places of Some Disease Bearing Mosquitoes and the Limits Which Determine the Latter, by Henry Rose Carter, [19--]
div1.p:
What of the breeding places preferential or compulsory of the
mosquitoes vectors of malaria? The problem here is quite different from
that on which we have just touched. The vector of yellow fever we may
assume to be, in the Americas at least, a single species of a single
genus and subgenus. The vector of malaria is, so far as our present know-
ledge and probability goes, confined to a single genus indeed, but a number
of species of that genus convey malaria. These different species might
naturally have different breeding places both preferential and of compulsion,
and it is rather the variation in the choice of their breeding places when
there is choice and the utilization of less preferable ones where there is
no choice of a few species of malaria carrying anopheles, that I shall touch
on in the remaining 10 minutes.

For the first, one might instance a species - anopheles cruzii - as
I recall, but am not sure - breeding in the axils of certain arborescent plants
- biomelias - in Southern Brazil and reported by Chagas as efficient malaria
vectors, and one, at least, in the Philippines, also a vector, is reported as
breeding in hamboo stumps and similar places by choice not to mention A. Macu-
latus breeding in the current of mountain streams in the Federated Malay
States. I have no first-hand knowledge of either.

I will confine myself then to the malaria vectors of the U. S. of
which I have some first-hand knowledge. Smith of New Jersey, a careful man
and a good entomologist, said some years ago that anopheles were found in
every kind of collection of water. As he was referring to the species of
Anopheles, crucians, punctipennis and quadrimaculatus, prevalent in New Jersey
and to normal breeding, he probably was not confining himself to breeding places
-2-
of sanitary importance. As this is the only class of breeding we consider
we certainly cannot accept this dictum for the states south and southwest
of New Jersey. For quadrimaculatus we have ponds, large pools, seepage
outcrops and certain marshes as breeding places of election; for puncti-
pennis, eddies and pools in streams, even swift streams, especially if
there is floatage present or grass hanging over in them, small pools,
cow tracks, and etc.; for curcians, water somewhat contaminated, with sea
water, (Even a higher salinity than normal sea-water in pools made so by
evaporation and refilling with sea-water) brackish or absolutely undrinkable
on the Atlantic Coastal plain, with acid, as Metz found them near Montgomery,
Ala. in 1918, and as the result of vegetable decomposition, if not too much
of it - just short of that suitable for full Urataeneus saphirrhims breed-
ing. This is not a requisite, however, only a preference. Crucians
breed freely in what we consider clean water.

Yet, while there is over-lapping of crucians into other than its
preferential breeding places on very moderate compulsion, the choice of the
other two species in a place for oviposition is well marked. In our work
for determining the effect of impounding water on the production of Anophe-
les, we found punctipennis larvae (except A. punctipennis in spring and
fall) so rarely in the large ponds that when we found them we looked for
the streams down which they might have washed and very generally found it.

The preference of quadrimaculatus for pond breeding leads to an
entirely logical but unexpected result. I say entirely logical. Imagine
a herd of cattle on a Texas prairie (thin feeding places); they gather and
feed in the swales when it is dry, on the hillocks when it is wet; but let
-3-
someone remove the fence from around a field of alfalfa, in the
prairie, they forsake both swales and hillocks and gather in the
alfalfa. So it seems that if a breeding place of election is made
sufficiently available to our Anopheles she will, or may, abandon other
breeding places which, while not her first choice, were sufficiently
acceptable to her to use.

So in the survey of the pool of lock No. 12 on the Coosa in
Alabama, a pool with over 25 miles of back water, we found breeding of
Anopheles quadrimaculatus in only one place (a large pool close to the
pond and which possibly had been joined to it) within say one-quarter
or one-half mile of the pool, while at a distance- as at Shelby, three
miles distant - and in country in all respects the same as that close
to the pool this species was breeding in every place (seepage outcrop
and large pool) we would expect to find them. So far the pond at
Parr's Shoals on Broad River, South Carolina, the same absence of quadri-
maculatus was found near the pool while a survey made at Eau Claire, some
15 miles distant and later at Camp Jackson - both in country so far as
we could see, like that adjoining Parr's Shoals showed this species fairly
common. Both of these ponds were breeding quadrimaculatus in places pro-
tected from fish and wave action. Never have I seen quadrimaculatus breed-
ing of sanitary importance close to one of the large hydro-electric ponds.

In the fall of 1921 - in a survey - I found a series of large
pools close to a fair-sized pond on Broad River at Lockhart, South Carolina.
These pools were large, some, I judge 40 by 20 feet - and there were at
-4-
least 20 of them. I fully expected to find quadrimaculatus in them but
I did not. I cannot say, of course, that this was due to the proximity
of the pond, because I made no survey in this immediate country at a
distance from this pond. Still, I did expect to find quads there and
would have found them in such ponds almost anywhere else in similar country.
I would give other examples from my own observations.

Data illustrating this principle, although it is not enunciated
as a principle, is given by the Swellengrebels and by Schuffner in the re-
ports of the Health Service of Dutch East Indies, No. 7 of 1919.

The Swellengrebels give data to show that, while sea-water is an
obligatory condition for the breeding of the coast strain of Anopheles
ludlowi, the principal vector for malaria about the coast of the Dutch
East Indies, the presence of a certain algae determines its preferential
breeding place - larvae of this species having been found in no fresh water
ponds, and in numbers in all salt-ponds containing this algae and in only
three out of 98 which did not contain it.

Schuffner at Deliwan found ludlowi breeding in a number of salt
ponds, in the grass growing and hanging over in them, in a few, freely. When
this algae appeared in some of these ponds, ludlowi bred profusely in them
and breeding ceased in the others.

An instance is also given when on the construction of a sea-fish pond,
(planted with the algae) breeding ceased in the natural salt-ponds in which
some breeding had been going on, the sea-fish pond breeding profusely.

Although as I said there was no enunciation of the principle we have
just formulated, yet the data these men give is good evidence for its existence.

No other species of Anopheles breeds in artificial containers
in the U. S. so as to be of sanitary importance. They do breed with us
in such containers - fire-barrels, buckets and in some sections more than
others, but nowhere have we seen them or doing so sufficiently to be a
sanitary problem. The same, from the report of others, seems to be true in
Europe, France, Spain, Italy, the Balkans and Greece. Indeed it may be
taken as a general characteristic of this genus - I cannot say a universal
one as I do not know, yet a strange tale comes to us from Russia. There
was a severe epidemic of malaria in Southeastern Russia in 1922 and 1923,
in which the vectors for much of the time were Anopheles bred in artificial
containers.

An account of this is given in the London Lancet of December 8,
1923, by Dr. Melville D. Mackensie, Medical Officer of the Friends' Russian
Famine Relief Unit, South East Russia. The district of which he was imme-
diately in charge was that of Buzuluk Ooyezd in the lower Volga valley, and was,
he stated, about the size of Wales, with a population of about 400,000.
He states that this epidemic extended over enormous areas in this valley in
which subtertian malaria had been previously unknown and where simple tertian
had been rare, making it at the time the most malarious region on the earth.

The infection was introduced in the fall of 1922 by human carriers
returning from Turkestan where malaria of all types is endemic and where they
had been to get wheat on account of the famine. They returned infected and
began to infect the home people in November. The epidemic continued throughout
the whole winter until May, when this account closes, although the temperature
recorded varied between -20 C to -30 C from 4 F to 22 F below zero. The
disease not only developed during this time in those already infected but was
-6-
contracted all during the winter. The houses were kept very close and
both the Anopheles vectors were breeding in the water-butts - larvae being a-
bundant in them and imagoes abundant in the dark corners of the houses.

He states that taking the average of all districts from 60 to 70
percent of the population were affected: in some 90 to 100 percent. It
was of all types - tertian, sub-tertian, and quartian - 14000 blood examinations
were made in the clinic at Buzuluk - and it was severe.

Mackenzie does not give the morbidity in his district, unless we
take it at 65% of 400, 000, which would give 260,000, nor the mortality al-
though he says it was high, nor - and more important to us - although an M. D.
and A. D. T. M. and a D. P. H. he did not think to mention the species of
Anopheles he found breeding in the water-butts - the vector responsible for
this malaria. Until we know the normal breeding habits of this mosquito
we cannot tell whether the water-butts were utilized from compulsion or were
its normal breeding places. There is nothing in this account to show why
they should have been utilized this winter - 1922 and 1923 - rather than
any previous one, and until we know more about its normal breeding habits
during the winter in this region we cannot claim that a change of such habits
were a factor in this epidemic. One would rather ascribe it to: (1) the
advent of carriers - especially as they brought an unaccustomed type of ma-
laria; (2) the debilitated state of the population -having thus no re-
sistance to even the tertian malaria, to which they were partly accustomed:
(3) the scarcity of quinine intensifying 2.

Naturally the house breeding of the Anopheles present was a factor,
and a necessary factor for new infections after cold weather set in, but I see
-7-
no reason why this should have been greater than in other years, unless
the people were too debilitated to fight against them. Naturally a man
on the ground should be the best judge of what measures are feasible and
McKensie says that was impossible to control this production of Anopheles
in the houses. Admitting that he was in a better position to judge yet
to the writer this looks as if it had been ridiculously easy by putting spigots in
the barrels low down and covering them with cloth or oiling the surface of the water
in them.

One would like much to have further news from this region and to
know (1) the species of anopheles concerned in this epidemic: (2) whether it
habitually bred in houses in previous winters and, if not, what condition was
changed so as to induce it to do so the winter of 1922 and 1923: (3) whether
it breeds in the house during the summer also; this seems to be a marshy country
with an abundance of possible breeding places, outside. We will watch for the
translation of the report of the Pan-Russian Malaria Conference at Moscow in
January last. It may be noted here that to it were reported 4,887,207 cases of
malaria in Russia, from January to October, 1923. This, say the local authori-
ties must be multiplied by 2 1/2 to obtain anything like the correct figure - giving
what seems to be good reasons therefore. This would give 12,218,000 cases of
malaria for these ten months. Well there are many people in Russia.
COPY:H

THE PREFERENTIAL AND COMPULSORY BREEDING PLACES OF SOME DISEASE BEARING
MOSQUITOES AND THE LIMITS WHICH DETERMINE THE LATTER BY DR. ROSE CARTER
DISCUSSION

DR. AGRAMONTEn said he would like to call attention to a means that
has been carried out for the first time in Santiago, for combatting the breeding
places of mosquitoes under conditions where the people had to keep reservoirs.
All water, had fish introduced so as to destroy the larvae in such places.

The discussion by Dr. Carter is one more example in our science of what
the intelligent man can do in combatting the mosquito. In this case the excellent
results are to be expected, particularly for the reason that the intelligent and
ingenuity are of a character far superior to the ordinary man.

THE PREFERENTIAL AND COMPULSORY BREEDING PLACES OF SOME DISEASE BREEDING
MOSQUITOES AND THE LIMITS WHICH DETERMINE THE LATTER BY DR. ROSE CARTER
DISCUSSION

DR. HORN opened the discussion with regard to the breeding of mosquitoes in lagoons.
He said covering 20 years experience, he carefully examined the whole range of
mosquitoes and he was never able to find any stagomia.........

We know that the stagomia is practically a in mosquito
In a town of perhaps 4,000 inhabitants, we kept the water supply free from mos-
quitoes and the water containers destroyed that would gather stagomia.

As to the question of the drainage, one of the greatest points I think....
...........

THE PREFERENTIAL AND COMPULSORY BREEDING PLACES OF SOME DISEASE-BEARING
MOSQUITOES AND THE LIMITS WHICH DETERMINE THE LATTER By Dr. Carter
DISCUSSION

DR. CARTER said that Dr. Horn has just said he would not mind the
mosquitoes breeding in or about the lagoons, my report did not assert that, it
applied to the draining of the lagoon and the cure of the mosquito breeding, in
connection with yellow fever. As I said, we can eb a slight change of our methods
control stagomia and and induce them not to form these outlying breeding places.
Their normal breeding places are pools, etc.

Dr. Carter quoted a letter from a Dr. Carr with regard to breeding in
puddles. They placed sand and packed it around as tightly as possible, he had
induced captive stagomia to deposit eggs about the centre above the sand.
I wrote him at once that this might start a strain that might breed on sand insta
instead of on land.
